description: A monumental 20-meter aluminum statue standing atop Sololaki Hill, overlooking Tbilisi. Created by renowned Georgian sculptor Elguja Amashukeli in 1958 to commemorate the city's 1500th anniversary, this iconic figure has become the symbol of Tbilisi and Georgia itself, embodying the nation's culture, history, identity, and resilience.
highlights: Standing 20 meters tall, visible from many miles away across the city
Depicts a woman in traditional Georgian dress holding symbolic objects in both hands
Left hand holds a bowl of wine representing Georgian hospitality and friendship
Right hand grips a sword symbolizing readiness to defend against enemies
Panoramic views of Tbilisi's old town, Mtkvari River, and surrounding hills
Illuminated at night, creating a striking silhouette against the sky
Located next to Narikala Fortress on the same hilltop
Accessible via scenic cable car ride from Rike Park
QR code at the statue connects to voice recording with information
tips: Take the cable car from Rike Park to Narikala Fortress, then walk a short distance (most popular route)
Alternative: hike up the stairway on Betlemi Street (20 minutes to 1 km walk)
Cable car tickets are cash only, approximately 12 Georgian Lari for return ticket
Cable car operates from 10 AM to midnight daily
Visit during sunset for magical atmosphere as city lights begin to twinkle
Morning and late-day visits offer cooler temperatures, fewer crowds, and best light for photography
Wear comfortable shoes as the walk up can be steep
Bring water, especially in summer, as the climb and sun can be dehydrating
The statue is on the edge of a hill, so you can only view it from the back, but walk down nearby stairs for good photos from the front
Small coffee and drink places available at the top to enjoy the views
Best seasons to visit: spring (April-June) and autumn (September-October) for mild weather and clear skies
Combine visit with nearby Narikala Fortress (5-minute walk), Botanical Gardens, and Abanotubani sulfur baths
vibe: Monumental and inspiring, standing as a proud guardian over the city. The hilltop location creates a sense of grandeur and timelessness, while the dual symbolism of wine and sword perfectly captures Georgia's famous dichotomy: warm, generous hospitality toward friends and fierce, unwavering defense against foes. The sweeping panoramic views and the statue's powerful presence evoke both national pride and contemplation of Georgia's complex history.
expectations: A massive, imposing aluminum monument dominating the skyline
Clear views of the entire city from the hilltop vantage point
Easy access via modern cable car system
A solemn, formal monument typical of Soviet-era commemorative art
Ability to walk around and photograph the statue from all angles
reality: The statue truly is massive and visible across the city, living up to its iconic status
The panoramic views are absolutely breathtaking and often described as the best in Tbilisi
Cable car ride is quick (couple of minutes) and scenic, offering great views during ascent
While Soviet-era in origin, the statue has transcended its period to become a beloved, enduring symbol embraced by modern Georgians
You can only view the statue from behind due to its position on the hill's edge - need to walk down stairs for frontal photos
The site has a relaxed atmosphere with cafes where you can linger and enjoy the vista
The combination with nearby Narikala Fortress makes it a comprehensive historical experience
Evening illumination transforms the statue into a dramatic, glowing beacon over the city
unique_facts: Originally designed to be temporary and made of wood when installed in 1958
Public reception was so positive that it was made permanent and covered in aluminum in 1963
The 1963 aluminum version was replaced with an identical new statue in 1997 to preserve this central feature of Tbilisi's skyline
Sculptor Elguja Amashukeli won the prestigious 1966 Shota Rustaveli State Prize for this work
Amashukeli originally called the statue 'Capital,' but Georgians began calling it 'Kartlis Deda,' which became so widespread it was officially renamed
The statue represents the 1500th anniversary of Tbilisi's founding, making it a relatively recent addition despite feeling timeless
At 20 meters tall, it's roughly equivalent to a 6-7 story building
The dual symbolism (wine bowl and sword) has become a shorthand for explaining Georgian national character to visitors
Despite being a Soviet-era monument, it avoided being torn down after independence because it had become genuinely beloved
The statue stands on Sololaki Hill, one of the most historic and picturesque areas of old Tbilisi
surprises: The statue is only viewable from the back when you first arrive - you must walk down stairs to photograph the front
There's a vibrant cafe culture at the viewing area, making it less solemn than expected
The original wooden version survived 5 years before being replaced with aluminum
Cable car tickets must be purchased with cash, not cards
The monument was created by a single artist who won Georgia's highest artistic prize for it
The wine bowl in her left hand actually represents a specific cultural practice - Georgians traditionally greet friends with wine
You can access a voice recording about the statue via QR code on site
The statue's location provides views not just of tourist areas but of residential Tbilisi, showing real city life
Many locals consider the statue a meeting point and cultural landmark, not just a tourist attraction
The hill position means you get 360-degree views, not just of the city but also the surrounding mountains and countryside
